awd_titl_txt: Elements:  Software - Harnessing the InSAR Data Revolution: GMTSAR
awd_abstract_narration:
The award supports the development of a software tool aimed at lowering the barriers for the use of Interferometric Synthetics Aperture Radar (InSAR) data. Natural processes such as earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, and glaciers cause deformation of the surface of the earth that can now be monitored to 10 mm precision globally.  These surface measurements provide a new tool for investigating processes in the interior of the Earth. InSAR is a powerful and low-cost way to monitor subsurface magma movement and is especially useful when combined with other tools such as GPS and seismic data.  InSAR is also used to understand subsurface fluid movement, such as caused by groundwater withdrawal, geothermal production, or in oil and gas fields. A wide variety of new SAR satellites are currently operating and the US will have an even more capable mission in the near future.  These massive data sets need to be transformed into information to promote the progress of science, mitigate natural  hazards, and enhance use of underground resources. The software, named GMTSAR will develop robust and sustainable software to take full advantage of the satellite generated data for both science and applications.  The main innovation of this project is to develop open and robust software to simplify the InSAR data processing and enable routine processing of thousands of SAR images on state-of-the-art computer facilities.  Open distribution of software, and the GMTSAR theoretical basis document provide a foundation for education in the field of space geodesy and ensures availability to a diverse audience.

This proposed investigation will use standard software engineering practices to harden the GMTSAR code, improve the geodesy, and make it more accessible to novice and advanced users on a wide array of UNIX platforms.  This will be achieved through improved and automated testing, partial redesign and simplification of the work flows, UNAVCO short courses, user feedback, and eventual migration of the code distribution and maintenance to a national facility. Work will be performed by a postdoctoral researcher in collaboration with the GMTSAR and GMT development teams and with assistance from the XSEDE program. The expected outcome is to provide sustainable, open, geodetically-accurate software to move InSAR time series analysis from the intermediate-scale methods published today to large spatial and time scale analyses that are becoming possible using the new data streams.

This award by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Cross-Cutting Activities Program of the Division of Earth Sciences within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences, and the EarthCube Program jointly sponsored by the NSF Directorate for Geosciences and the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

 Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) is a powerful technique for measuring small displacements (1-10 cm) of the surface of the Earth including those caused by tectonic loading, earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, glaciers, ground fluid injection/withdrawal and underground nuclear tests. Understanding these processes and their associated hazards is a top priority of the Earth science community, and InSAR analysis provides a unique advantage over other space-based datasets in that it allows for continuous spatial coverage anywhere on Earth, in day or night, regardless of weather conditions. Over the past decade, we have developed a freely available, open-source software to harness these valuable datasets. During this investigation, funded by the NSF Geoinformatics and Cyberinfrastructure program, we equipped GMTSAR with the power to capitalize on the freely available ~1,200 TBytes per year of data being collected by the European Space Agency (ESA) operated Sentinel-1 satellite system, and provided this robust research tool to our user base. 

Intellectual Merit

This investigation equipped solid earth and cryosphere scientists with software to utilize the massive InSAR data sets to advance their interdisciplinary investigations, including global observations of volcanoes, estimates of seismic hazard through strain-rate mapping, monitoring urban infrastructure, tracking ice sheet movements and detecting coastal subsidence. The global reach of InSAR science was advanced by streamlined processing modules that are accessible to both specialists and students alike. The specific outcomes include:

1)    Improved software distribution by moving the version control to github. The new WIKI page ( https://github.com/gmtsar/gmtsar/wiki/GMTSAR-Wiki-Page ) describes the installation and operation for basically all UNIX and now Windows 10 systems.

2)    Developed procedures for testing the code on 5 different UNIX platforms. 

3)    Developed and distributed modules for split-spectrum ionospheric correction as well as solid Earth tide correction (only nerds will care about this). 

4)    Hosted annual GMTSAR short courses 2018 - 2022.  The 2018, 2019 courses were held in person at UCSD with 25, and 27 students respectively.  Due to COVID restrictions the 2020 - 2022 short courses were done remotely and had 160, 140, and 130 students, respectively.  The course agenda and educational materials are available at https://www.unavco.org/event/2022-short-course-insar-processing-and-theory-with-gmtsar/ .

5)    We have engaged more researchers in the development and maintenance of the software. There is a very active user forum at the github site. Xiaohua (Eric) Xu has made over 230+ replies to questions on this forum. We also host the github issue page https://github.com/gmtsar/gmtsar/issues, where we have 390+ opened issues with most (302) being properly addressed (we leave issues open for half year in case users come back with more to report). Xiaohua (Eric) Xu also has 500+ email changes with researchers from all over the world. 

6)    We developed detailed instructions on how to compute combined InSAR/GNSS time series from Sentinel-1 data. http://topex.ucsd.edu/gmtsar/tar/sentinel_time_series_3.pdf

 

Broader Impacts

Funding was used to support two masters students, an early-career researcher and train a postdoc in best practices for software development, NSF funding also supported the creation and expansion of a web-based GMTSAR documentation center.  Moreover, we continued to educate the user community through UNAVCO short courses and user forums. UNAVCO-hosted short courses have become an increasingly popular means of educating new and current users of GMTSAR software, and these courses, in combination with expanded documentation, empowered users to harness the available and future InSAR data for further global earth science research.
